ns:common.topic.description: Oaklisp is a portable object-oriented Scheme by Kevin J. Lang and Barak A. Pearlmutter while Computer Science PhD students at Carnegie Mellon University. Oaklisp uses a superset of Scheme syntax. It is based on generic operations rather than functions, and features anonymous classes, multiple inheritance, a strong error system, setters and locators for operations, and a facility for dynamic binding.\nVersion 1.2 includes an interface, bytecode compiler, run-time system and documentation.
rdfs:label: Oaklisp

ns:common.document.text: Oaklisp is a portable object-oriented Scheme by Kevin J. Lang and Barak A. Pearlmutter while Computer Science PhD students at Carnegie Mellon University. Oaklisp uses a superset of Scheme syntax. It is based on generic operations rather than functions, and features anonymous classes, multiple inheritance, a strong error system, setters and locators for operations, and a facility for dynamic binding.\nVersion 1.2 includes an interface, bytecode compiler, run-time system and documentation.\nThis article was originally based on material from the Free On-line Dictionary of Computing, which is licensed under the GFDL.

ns:type.object.name: Oaklisp
